importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the presidential runoff election in Bolivia, marking the culmination of a highly contested political transition.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period of economic deterioration in Bolivia since 2023, including dollar shortages, fuel shortages, and soaring inflation, provides context for the political crisis and the necessity of reform.

keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator, won Bolivia's presidential runoff election with 54% of the vote, defeating right-wing candidate Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga who received 45%.
Paz's victory reflects widespread public dissatisfaction with the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party's 20-year rule and economic mismanagement.
Paz's campaign, led by the slogan 'capitalism for all,' appealed to working-class and rural voters disillusioned with MAS's high taxes and regulations.

His running mate, ex-cop Edman Lara, gained massive popularity through viral TikTok videos denouncing corruption and promised universal income and higher pensions, adding a populist and authentic edge to the campaign.
Paz plans to end the fixed exchange rate, phase out fuel subsidies, and reduce public investment, but will maintain MAS-style social benefits to avoid economic collapse.
The country faces severe economic challenges, including a 23% inflation rate, fuel shortages, and a shortage of U.S. dollars that has hampered imports and savings.
Paz pledged to avoid IMF involvement and instead rely on fighting corruption, reducing waste, and restoring currency confidence to attract dollar savings.
Despite his promises, critics argue that his fiscal policies are vague and may fail to deliver on economic stability.
Paz's victory marks a significant political shift, breaking the long dominance of MAS and signaling a new era of political renewal in Bolivia.

The win reflects a clear class divide: Paz won support from Indigenous and working-class voters in the Andean highlands and coca-producing regions, while Quiroga represented wealthier, politically entrenched elites in the eastern lowlands.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator and son of former president Jaime Paz Zamora, has won Bolivia’s presidential runoff election with 54% of the vote, defeating right-wing candidate Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga. This victory marks a significant shift in a country long dominated by the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party, which has faced growing public frustration over economic mismanagement, inflation, and fuel shortages. Paz's campaign, supported by the Christian Democratic Party, appeals to working-class and Indigenous voters in regions like Cochabamba and the Andean highlands with a platform of 'capitalism for all' and gradual reform. His running mate, ex-cop Edman Lara, gained traction through viral anti-corruption videos, bringing a populist, authentic edge to the race. Despite promises to end the fixed exchange rate, phase out fuel subsidies, and reduce public spending, Paz faces criticism over vague fiscal plans and potential economic instability. Bolivia now faces an uphill battle to stabilize its economy, recover foreign currency reserves, and restore confidence in its currency, all while navigating a deep political and class divide between urban elites and rural, working-class communities.
title: Centrist Rodrigo Paz wins Bolivia's presidential runoff, topping right-wing rival
